description: plural +‎ -ity, from Middle English pluralite, from Old French pluralité (“multitude, state of being plural”), from Latin plūrālitās.

entries.meaning: (countable) A number or part of a whole which is greater than any other number or part, but not necessarily a majority.

(countable) A number of votes for a single candidate or position which is greater than the number of votes gained by any other single candidate or position voted for, but which is less than a majority of valid votes cast.
(countable) A margin by which a number exceeds another number, especially of votes.
examples: Truman's total vote was 24,104,836. Dewey received 21,969,500; […] . Truman won by a plurality of 2,135,336, but it was the first time since 1916 that a winner has failed to capture a majority of all votes cast.

entries.meaning: (countable) A group of many entities: a large number.
examples: A plurality of ideas were put forth at the meeting, most of which were rejected out of hand.

entries.meaning: (countable) A group composed of more than one entity.
examples: The array is organized into a plurality of vertical (column) blocks.

entries.meaning: (psychology) The condition of a single body/person displaying multiple distinct personas.
